comprehensibility.notes: Clear presentation of software co-development framework; minor terminology gaps for non-technical readers

transparency.notes: Strong code availability (GitHub, GPLv3); supplementary materials lack DOIs; conflict of interest undisclosed

plausibility.notes: Claims consistent with domain knowledge and established software engineering principles

validity.notes: Appropriate qualitative design; quantitative claims based on informal self-reported metrics

robustness.notes: Limited by three case studies, positive selection bias, and absence of failure cases

generalisability.notes: Diverse contexts but resource-intensive model limits applicability to well-funded projects

reproducibility.notes: Excellent software availability; process documentation good but support-dependent; analytical methods informal

caveats.description: Authors include FAIMS development team with financial/professional stake in FAIMS success
caveats.impact: May affect objectivity of cost-benefit assessments

caveats.description: Quantitative claims (time savings, costs) are self-reported estimates without documented methodology
caveats.impact: Specific numbers should be interpreted as indicative rather than precise

caveats.description: Case studies represent volunteer early adopters; failed or rejected deployments not represented
caveats.impact: Generalisation to reluctant adopters or resource-constrained projects limited
